summary.title: Demo Threat Model
summary.description: A sample model of a web application, with a queue-decoupled background process.

threats.mitigation:
Encrypt the DB credentials in the configuration file.

Expire and replace the DB credentials regularly.
threats.description: The Background Worker configuration stores the credentials used by the worker to access the DB. An attacker could compromise the Background Worker and get access to the DB credentials.
threats.title: Accessing DB credentials

threats.description: An attacker could make an query call on the DB,
threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.mitigation: Require all queries to be authenticated.

threats.description: An attacker could obtain the DB credentials and use them to make unauthorised queries.
threats.title: Credential theft
threats.mitigation: Use a firewall to restrict access to the DB to only the Background Worker IP address.

threats.title: Credentials should be encrypted
threats.description: The Web Application Config stores credentials used by the Web App to access the message queue. These could be stolen by an attacker and used to read confidential data or place poison message on the queue.
threats.mitigation: The Message Queue credentials should be encrypted.

threats.title: Message secrecy
threats.description: The data flow between the Web Application and the Background Worker is not point-to-point and therefore end-to-end secrecy cannot be provided at the transport layer. Messages could be read by an attacker at rest in the Message Queue.
threats.mitigation: Use message level encryption for high sensitivity data (e.g. security tokens) in messages.

threats.title: Message tampering
threats.description: Messages on the queue could be tampered with, causing incorrect processing by the Background Worker.
threats.mitigation: Sign all queue messages at the Web Server. Validate the message signature at the Background Worker and reject any message with a missing or invalid signature. Log any failed messages.

threats.title: Fake messages could be placed on the queue
threats.description: An attacker could put a fake message on queue, causing the Background Worker to do incorrect processing.
threats.mitigation:
Restrict access to the queue to the IP addresses of the Web Server and Background Worker.

Implement authentication on the queue endpoint.

threats.title: Poison messages 1
threats.description: An attacker could generate a malicious message that the Background Worker cannot process.
threats.mitigation: Implement a poison message queue where messages are placed after a fixed number of retries.
Validate the content of all messages, before processing. Reject any message that have invalid content and log the rejection. Do not log the malicious content - instead log a description of the error.
threats.title: Poison messages 2
threats.description: An attacker could generate a malicious message that the Background Worker cannot process.
These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.
threats.title: Data flow should use HTTP/S
threats.mitigation: The requests should require HTTP/S. This will provide confidentiality and integrity. HTTP should not be supported.
The requests should require HTTP/S. This will provide confidentiality and integrity. HTTP should not be supported.
threats.title: Data flow should use HTTP/S
threats.description: These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.

threats.title: Man in the middle attack
threats.mitigation: Enforce an encrypted connection at the DB server
threats.description: An attacker could intercept the DB queries in transit and obtain sensitive information, such as DB credentials, query parameters or query results (is unlikely since the data flow is over a private network).

threats.title: Data flow should use HTTP/S
threats.description: These responses are over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.
threats.mitigation: The requests should require HTTP/S. This will provide confidentiality and integrity. HTTP should not be supported.

data.name: Read web app config
data.reasonOutOfScope: This data flow represents a read from the file system

data.name: Read worker config
data.reasonOutOfScope: This data flow represents a read from the file system

threats.title: Data flow should use HTTP/S
threats.description: These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.
threats.mitigation: The requests should require HTTP/S. This will provide confidentiality and integrity. HTTP should not be supported.

A Demo Threat Model
showing an example web application,
with a queue-decoupled background process
